newsitem.title: UK: Unionists leave N.Ireland talks in arms row.
newsitem.headline: Unionists leave N.Ireland talks in arms row.

text.p: Pro-British Unionist parties withdrew from Wednesday's session of Northern Ireland peace talks in a row over British proposals on the surrender of guerrilla weapons.

Members of the Ulster Unionist party (UUP), Democratic Unionist party (DUP) and the U.K. Unionist party (UKUP) decided not to continue with Wednesday's session saying their questions about the issue had not been answered by the British government.
"We share the irritation -- not the irritation, the anger that some elements of clarification are being withheld," David Trimble, leader of the UUP, the province's biggest party, said.

Unionists are angry that Britain has resumed contact with Sinn Fein, political wing of IRA guerrillas, to give clarification on proposals to "decommission" arms held by extremist groups. Sinn Fein is banned from the talks until the IRA calls a truce.
Party spokesmen said they would return to the next session of the talks on Monday but were not optimistic of progress. "I'll be back to watch over the obsequies," said UK Unionist Robert McCartney.
